_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



I. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Safety and security receive the highest priority at the Afton Chemical Corporation-Houston Plant manufacturing facility in Pasadena, Texas. Afton believes that effective safety management requires the concurrent implementation of three basic concepts:

1. Each individual is responsible and accountable for his or her own safety,

2. Afton Chemical Corporation has the responsibility to provide a safe work environment,

3. As a responsible individual, each employee has a duty to also care for the safety of his coworkers and appropriately discuss safety behavior with each other.



Management wants to have one of the safest manufacturing facilities in the chemical industry and has set its goal to be "zero OSHA recordable injuries". Integral to zero OSHA recordable injuries is preventing accidental chemical releases that could potentially harm employees or members of the public.



The plant maintains detailed manuals with information and procedures for its safe and secure operation. Frequent training sessions provide the employees and contractors the knowledge and skills needed for conducting safe operations. The manuals also contain detailed information on the nature of the chemicals and equipment present in the plant, the safe modes for operating the equipment and handling the chemicals, and the procedures to be followed in the event of accidental release or other emergency event. Management supports the active participation of employees in the Channel Industries Mutual Aid organization (CIMA) comprised of the areas neighboring chemical manufacturers. Routine drills are carried out at various members' facilities to practice emergency responses to hypothetical fire, explosion, and chemical release scenarios. Members of our emergency response teams receive annual training at the Texas A&M Fire School and annual refresher training as Hazmat Technicians. Many members are certified Emerg

ency Medical Technicians and Fire Fighters with many years of chemical plant experience.



II. RMP Regulated Substances at the Afton Chemical Corporation-Houston Plant



The Afton Chemical Corporation-Houston Plant is located approximately one mile north of Highway 225 on N. South Street in Pasadena, Texas. The plant began operation in 1952 as Ethyl Corporation. In 1994 Ethyl spun off major portions of the plant to Albemarle Corporation. The Ethyl Lube Additives plant in October of 2015 was transfer to a sister division, Afton Chemical, a subsidiary of NewMarket Corporation. The present Afton Chemical plant manufactures over 100 million pounds annually of specialty lubricant additives and fuel additives, and serves as a distribution terminal for fuel additives. The lubricant and fuel additives are oil-based polyalkylphenols, polyaklylphenylamines, and polyisobutylene compounds. The plant uses two chemicals above the threshold quantities listed the EPA Risk Management Plan rule to carry out the chemical reactions that are part of producing the additives; chlorine and 44% formaldehyde.



Chlorine



A 90-ton capacity rail car of chlorine is positioned inside the plant, in a secured fenced perimeter with locking man gates, to feed the polyisobutylene PIBSA process where it serves as a reaction promoter. The polyisobutylene process produces oil-based lubricant additives. The process uses approximately 5 to 6 rail cars of chlorine per year. This annual usage makes it impractical to use the smaller, 1-ton chlorine cylinders. As a passive mitigation control, only one chlorine rail car is allowed in the process unload area of the plant and a second one is stored in the plant storage yard for a temporary period of time while the process railcar is being emptied. There is a logistics ordering procedure to order a replacement railcar when the railcar in the storage yard is spotted on the process unload spot to replace the railcar which was emptied. This helps reduce the num

ber of days a second railcar is on site.



Formaldehyde



Formaldehyde is brought into the plant by truck trailer. The formaldehyde is a solution composed of 44% formaldehyde, 1% methanol, and 55% water. It is unloaded from the truck trailer to a 61,000- gallon capacity storage tank (T-1203) in the Mannich dispersant area. Formaldehyde is one of four materials reacted in the Mannich Unit to produce gasoline performance additives.



III. Worst Case Scenario



Chlorine



The worst case scenario for chlorine is the structural failure of one, full rail car that releases the 90 tons (180,000 pounds) of gas over a ten-minute period. The wind speed is assumed to be low at 1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour) with an F-Stability class meteorological condition. An F-Stability class is a meteorological condition that gives little air turbulence and therefore a low level of mixing and dilution of the released gas. The EPA established the Toxic Endpoint for chlorine, based on the Emergency Response Planning Guideline-2, to be 0.0087 mg/l. Using the Look-Up Tables from the

EPA Off- Site Consequences Guidance Document the distance to the toxic end point is estimated to be 14 miles. The amount of chlorine present at the plant site is a one, 90-ton capacity rail car in the process unload area and a second one is stored in the plant storage yard for a temporary period of time while the process railcar is being emptied. The rail car is unloaded in an secured fenced area of the plant that is isolated from routine rail traffic. A derailer is placed across the rail tracks and locked on to prevent accidental movement by a train while the rail car is being unloaded. The rail car is not connected to any other cars and its wheels are chocked. There is 24-hour video surveillance of the chlorine rail car and 18 detectors at different elevations to alert personnel of a possible leak. The railcar unload angle valve has a automated closer which can be activated in the control room or locally

at the unload spot and close the valve in ~8 seconds. The unload hose has automated valves on each end of the hose which can be isolated in case of a hose failure. Operators make routine rounds to inspect the Chlorine system during their shift. Plant Operations and Plant Security monitor the video cameras of the chlorine unloading area.



IV. Alternative Release Scenarios



Chlorine



The Alternative Release Scenario for chlorine is a gasket failure at a flanged joint, upstream of the remote operated shutoff valve, in the one-inch unloading line connected to the rail car transfer hose system. The release rate is assumed to be 240 pounds per minute, which is just below the setting of the rail car's automatic, excess flow, shutoff valve. It is assumed the leak lasts 20 minutes before the emergency response crew stops it. The wind speed is assumed to be at 3.0 meters/second (6.8 miles/hour) with a D-Stability class meteorological condition. A D-Stability class is a meteorological

condition that gives little air turbulence and therefore a low level of mixing and dilution of the released gas. The EPA established the Toxic Endpoint for chlorine, based on the Emergency Response Planning Guideline-2, to be 0.0087 mg/l. Using the Look-Up Tables from the EPA Off- Site Consequences Guidance Document the distance to the toxic end point is estimated to be .30 miles. An emergency Chlorine "C" Kit is maintained on the unload platform of the chlorine rail car unloading rack. It has the materials needed to do an emergency-shutoff of the rail car. There is 24-hour video surveillance of the chlorine rail car and 18 detectors at different elevations around the railcar that would sound an alarm if chlorine above 1 ppm is detected, to alert personnel of a possible leak. The railcar unload angle valve has a automated closer which can be activated in the control room or locally at the unload spot and close the valve in ~8 seconds. The unload hose has automated valves on each end of th

e hose which can be isolated in case of a hose failure. Fire fighting equipment on site and fire monitors in the area would spray the downwind area to absorb and disperse the

escaping gas. Two surveillance cameras monitor the unloading spot 24 hours per day. Detailed written response procedures are in place.  Operators and emergency response personnel train periodically on the chlorine response procedures.



Formaldehyde



The Alternative Release Scenario for formaldehyde is the failure of the 3-inch rubber hose during the unloading of a truck trailer. It is estimated that the 19.8 pounds per minute for a period of 60 minutes would be spilled to the curbed concrete containment area in which the truck trailer is staged for unloading, before the valve on the truck trailer would be closed. The wind speed is assumed to be 3.0 meters/second (6.8 miles/hour) with a D-stability class meteorological condition. A D-stability class is a meteorological condition that gives little air turbulence and therefore a low level of mixing and dilution of the released gas. The EPA established the Toxic Endpoint for formaldehyde, based on the Emergency Response Planning Guideline-2, to be 0.012 mg/l. Using the Look-Up Tables from the EPA Off- Site Consequences Guidance Document the distance to the toxic end point is estimated to be 0.19 miles.



V. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



The Afton Chemical Corporation-Houston Plant uses the Process Hazards Analysis method as one means of identifying potential chemical process hazards. A well-documented ISO style system is in place to track the progress of resolving any potential hazards identified and to document their final engineered resolution. A corporate policy for Employee participation in the PHA process initiated in 1993 is followed. Employees have full access to the computer based PHA results and progress

tracking system.



Specific PHA reviews have been conducted for the Chl

orine Unloading System, and the Formaldehyde Unloading and Storage system. These reviews are periodically renewed at least every five years or as needed for planned process changes, in response to process incidents, or as required by schedule renewal dates.



Another element of the plant's accidental release prevention is it inspection and maintenance program to assure equipment mechanical integrity. The program is designed to assure mechanical integrity of all our process equipment and to fulfill the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management rules.



Over arching these programs is plant management's commitment to safe operations. Constant attention is given to see that the resources and individuals needed for the various prevention programs are available to insure the chemical accident prevention programs, such as the ones mentioned previously, are in place and current.



VI. Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of chlorine or formaldehyde at the Houston plant during the past five years that have resulted in death, injury, or property damage on-site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



VII. Emergency Response Program



The Afton Chemical Houston plant's emergency response program is carried out at three levels. First, there is a program internal to the Afton facilities. The written emergency response program covers all of the plant's facilities and the chemicals used. All employees and contract personnel receive periodic, mandatory training in the emergency response procedures. The program is under the leadership of the plant manager and a full time, safety professional. Second, the plant shares security and emergency response equipment and personnel from its adjacent neighbors, the Albemarle Corporation, GCL, Ethyl Corporation, and Enterprise Products. In the event of an emergency release, fire, or explosion trained security and emergency resp

onse personnel respond from Albemarle, GCL, Ethyl, and Enterprise Products in proportion to the level of need. Albemarle, GCL, Ethyl, and Enterprise Products are physically located on the same complex within the same fenced perimeter and they have external and internal access to the Afton plant at all times. Finally, Afton participates as a member of the Channel Industries Mutual Aid organization (CIMA). This organization is composed of over 100 local chemical and petrochemical plants who have an extensive array of fire fighting and emergency rescue equipment, and personnel which can be quickly mobilized to deal with all levels of emergency events that range from chemical releases, fires, or explosions. Quarterly, site wide drills are held which cover a wide range of emergency scenarios. The locations for the drills are rotated among the member's plants to build a broad depth of knowledge among the response personnel. The CIMA organization conducts annual inspections of the plant's fire systems and equipment to assure compliance with membership agreements. The plant also participates in an annual CIMA area drill involving other members of the CIMA organization. All of the responders are employees at the member plants who have received training in the various aspects of emergency response (e.g. fire fighting, hazardous materials, first aid, emergency medical treatment, personnel rescue). Our plant fire systems, such as deluge systems, chemical suppression systems, and building fire monitoring systems are inspected regularly by a certified inspection company.



IX. Overview of Plans to Improve Safety



The plan to continuously improve safety is based on improving the current safety systems and adding carefully selected new programs. The current safety programs include the Joint Labor and Management Safety Committee, Process Hazard Analyses (initial and periodic renewals), OSHA Process Safety Management systems, employee safety training, and Safety, Security, Health,

and Environmental Incident Investigations. In the past, investigations were directed at recordable

incidents and safety performance were measured by tracking the number of OSHA recordable and lost time injuries. This has been expanded to include good catches, and minor injuries that do not qualify as OSHA recordable. Investigating these incidents will allow corrective actions that may preempt more serious injuries. Including them in the performance measure will help to prevent complacency that might result from just observing very low recordable and lost time injury rates.
